abstract.p: Two new Web sites built on very different business models are planned to promote independent booksellers; American Booksellers Association plans Booksense.com, which will act as hub site for individual Web sites of hundreds of stores; Steven T Brill will offer Contentville, site on which independent stores will provide editorial content for fee, not sell books, and get equity stake in company should it go public; sales graph; photo (M)

block.p: Independent booksellers are a famously fractious group, as the name suggests. In their two-decades war against chain stores and, more recently, online booksellers, they have shared little beyond common enemies -- Barnes & Noble, Borders, Amazon, the price clubs -- and a will to survive.

Independent booksellers are a famously fractious group, as the name suggests. In their two-decades war against chain stores and, more recently, online booksellers, they have shared little beyond common enemies -- Barnes & Noble, Borders, Amazon, the price clubs -- and a will to survive.

Isolated from one another in neighborhoods across America, they have fought a guerrilla war with discouraging results. Nearly half the independent booksellers have disappeared since 1994, according to the American Booksellers Association.

Now the Internet, the site of so much recent loss for the independents, will take on greater importance as a battleground in the next two months. Set to debut are two large-scale Web sites that seek to promote the independents. But many wonder whether the sites are jumping in too late and can compete with the customer service of the online giants Amazon.com and Barnesandnoble.com.

On June 6, the booksellers association will begin to unveil Booksense.com, a site turning the independents into ''local store dot-com, closed but open 24 hours a day,'' says Michael Hoynes, the program's marketing officer. Next to come, in early July, is Contentville, a site produced by Steven T. Brill, which will, according to its senior vice president and e-publisher, Annik LaFarge, make some 40 of the most respected booksellers in the country the ''heart and soul'' of its book retailing area. The sites hope to showcase the independents as stores run by booksellers with personalities as unique and marketable as their books.

But they are built on very different business models. Booksense.com is a ''hub site'' for hundreds of individual Web sites created and maintained by local stores. Each will have its own Web address and set its own prices.

What is unusual about Contentville's relationship with the independent booksellers it has recruited -- Glenn Goldman of Book Soup in Los Angeles, Neal Sofman of A Clean Well Lighted Place in San Francisco and a former A.B.A. president, Ed Morrow of Northshire Bookstore in Manchester Center, Vt., among others -- is that the independents will not actually be selling books on Contentville.
Instead, they will provide editorial content for a fee and will get an equity stake in the company should Contentville go public.

Sara Farley, an e-commerce analyst at PaineWebber, believes the biggest issue for the new sites lies in customer service, exactly the territory the independents in Booksense.com, in particular, will have the least control over. ''The trick,'' she says, ''is providing a great customer experience. Amazon has spent five years developing a complicated and hopefully very robust distribution and fulfillment network. They didn't snap their fingers.''

To meet the challenge, the sites have established alliances with Baker & Taylor and Ingram, wholesalers that have traditionally dealt in bulk orders to booksellers and now face the challenge of shipping smaller orders directly to consumers' homes.

Ingram, for example, has worked over the last two years to improve its ability to ship smaller orders to more customers, and over the last year has developed this operation in earnest delivering books for Barnesandnoble.com and Buy.com, the two largest of 20 such clients it works with.

Ingram has a cash investment in Contentville, which ''gives us reassurance they'll do it right,'' said Mr. Brill. Booksense.com has reached similar distribution agreements with Baker & Taylor and other wholesalers. The wholesalers' ability to deliver on their promises is crucial, says Lorraine Shanley, a publishing consultant at Market Partners.
''The online component of bookselling is difficult for people without the resources and organizational savvy of Amazon,'' she said. ''A.B.A. is a trade organization.''

The obstacle, she says, is the same as it was for Barnes & Noble when it went online. ''They are trying to jerry-rig entrenched systems, as opposed to building a Web-based transactional business, which is what Amazon did,'' she said.

Len Vlahos, director of Booksense.com, says customer service will be the strength of the program. ''The local store itself will be point of customer contact,'' he said. ''There's an actual person in the store, which has many more years of customer service experience than Amazon.''

But the question still remains whether the Internet plays to the independents' strengths as retailers. Online booksellers can't replicate the experience of browsing and buying books in a store, says Jeffrey Fieler, consumer Internet analyst at Bear Stearns.

Though he acknowledges that ''the independents have to do something or they will be marginalized'' even further, he is skeptical that a niche retailer can develop a significant market share in a category already well-served on the Web. Last year, according to Mr. Fieler, people visited an average of 15 sites a month. This year, he says, the number has shrunk to 10.
''People are finding the places that meet their needs,'' he says. ''The larger sites in each area are adding functionality so that people don't need to go to other sites.''

Booksense.com, which has been delayed since the fall by technical problems, grows out of Booksense, a ''national marketing umbrella'' launched by the booksellers association for its beleaguered members in February 1999. In the last 16 months, Booksense has attracted 1,154 stores across the country to its offline program. It offers, among other features, a bestseller list drawn from members' stores, gift certificates redeemable at any affiliated store (allowing direct competition with the ubiquity of the chains) and national advertising promoting independents' reading recommendations.
Booksense.com charges participants a set-up fee, a monthly maintenance fee and takes 4.5 percent in commissions on orders shipped from wholesale partners.

The association has earmarked more than $2 million for promotion. Ms. Farley said Amazon had spent $40.6 million in advertising, promotion and public relations in the last quarter alone, though Amazon sells more than books.
Local marketing by the independents themselves, together with significant in-store promotion of the individual Web sites, is seen as key to Booksense's viability.

Mr. Fieler also sees risks in this limited approach. ''Partnerships with other sites that command large shares'' of Internet traffic, such as Barnes and Noble's relationship with AOL, or Amazon's relationship with Yahoo, will be crucial for the venture, he said.

Research from the American Booksellers Association shows, Mr. Hoynes says, that the typical customer of an independent bookstore buys an average of 20 books a year, but only 8 of those at an independent store. Booksense's goal is to build the independents' share to 10 or 11.

Contentville has significantly more marketing clout and will sell more than books: content from newspapers and magazines, as well as e-books, dissertations and other material. It will spend $75 million in advertising over the next two years, according to Mr. Brill, who estimates that books will account for 25 to 30 percent of the site's total revenue. Both NBC and CBS have invested in Contentville, and the site will be advertised on the networks beginning in July in some markets.

The Contentville independents will create a variety of editorial features, including recommended ''libraries'' of essential books in various categories, ''If You Ask Me'' endorsements of books they love and new books they are enthusiastic about. There will also be store bestseller lists and ''Buzz on the Floor'' notes on local happenings that have helped sales of certain titles. But Ms. Shanley questions whether the local flavor will help on the Web, where ''virtual communities are more important than land-based ones.''
The new sites are complementary -- Contentville will have pages that point back to Web sites that may be part of Booksense.

This may be an advantage for the booksellers involved in the programs. Roxanne Coady of R. J. Julia Books in Madison, Conn., who is participating in both sites, said: ''Booksense as a branding campaign, Booksense.com and Contentville can all act to remind consumers that independent booksellers have a valuable voice. That alone is a big deal.''
